div.p: LAWTRICKES OR, WHO WOVLD HAVE THOVGHT IT.
As it hath bene diuers times Acted by the Children of the Reuels.
LONDON Printed for Richard More, and are to be solde at his Shop in S. Dunstanes Church-yard in Fleetestrette. 1608.

div.head: The Booke to the Reader.
div.p: HOnest Reader, by thy patience, this is the first time of our meeting, & it may be the last, that's as we shal agree at parting, woot buy me, the stationer thankes thee; woot reade mee, doe: but picke no more out of me, then he that writ put into me: nor knowe me not better then he that made me: such Mechanicke gods this hil of Pernassus harbors: we haue a strange secte of vpstart Phisiognomers, growne vp amongst vs of late, that will assume out of the depth of their knowings, to calculate a mans intent by the colour of his complexion: nay, which is miraculous, by the character of his reporte: and tis wonderfull to consider: cannot an honest man speake to a knaue, but his language must needes be scand? a gallant to a Countrieman, must his intent be to rob? must a Cucckolde of consequent necessitie dwell at the Harts-horne? and a Musitian at the Cat & the fidle? strange interpretations. I say no more, but if the Cobler wold look no further then the shoe-latchet, we should not haue so many corrupt translations: for mine owne part I reuerence all modest aduertisements, and submit my selfe to any iudicious censurer, & protesting I neuer held my irregular course, but my Inke hath been alwaies simple, without the iuice of worm-wood, and my pen smooth without teeth, and so it shall continue.
Thine or any mans for a testar.

div.head: Law-tricks, OR Who would haue thought it.
ACTƲS PRIMƲS.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: DIuine inuention, O how I could hug,
And like an amorous Louer court thy beauty,
That crownst me King of pleasures! were my braine
Fordg'd out of vulgar metall without fier,
And sprightly motion, my big-swolne hopes,
Had bene still-borne, but when deiected minds,
Out slept the golden pleasure of the night:
My serious meditations haue out-watch'd,
The glorious tapers that attend the Moone:
I turnd my thoughts into a thousand shapes:
Moulded the fashion of ten thousand plots,
Lik'd and dislik'd so many, that my brayne
The mother of Inuention grew barrayne,
Almost past bearing, still my laboring thoughts
Conceiu'd a yet more strange and quaint Idea,
Gaue it proportion, and I brought it forth:
And that blest infant of Inuention
Beyond all hope hath my contentment woon,
And that's Loues heauen I loue a face more faire
Then Cintheas as hue that seems aboue compare,
But hell, her husband with a iealous eye
Vshers her steps, oh wedded slauery!
This tender rose, whom artles marriage,
Hath grafted on a nettle (testy age)
Haue I vngrafted, made himselfe vntie
The knot of wedlock: thanks sweete industrie.
And here a comes, that which most heaps my fame,
His wit's well spoken of.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This wit's a sprightly thing.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: For such as haue't.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It not alone doth bring,
Publique applause, but knowledge i'the law,
Teacheth to speake in distance.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: How the daw
Scoures ore his rustie phrases? honord Count,
How growes your plot?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My thriuing fortunes mount
Aboue suppose, euen to my harts content:
Wee are diuorc'd.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: My hopes are preualent.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You know the cause on't, two sufficient men
Swore her a harlot, and the partiall Bench
Inspirde by my good Angels (Angels wings
Sweepe a cleare passage to the seat of Kings)
Seald our diuorce.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But doth her brother swallow
This grosse abuse?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Abuse, away, away.
They know me rich Horatio, chinke, chinke:
Whilst this holds out, my cause shal neuer sincke.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: See where a comes, his sad complexion weares,
Griefs mourning liuery, he is clothde in teares.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Whence springs this sorrow?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For my sisters shame,
My sister, oh my sister, whose repute
Hung like a Jewell on her sexes forehead.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And what of her?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Shee is, o no she was
Pure as the Diamond, cleere as christall glasse,
But now, O hell, her credit is more foule,
Then speckled scandall, or black murders soule.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I cannot thinke it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But I know't too true,
She was my wife and by her meanes, my head
Was fayrely tupt and you will buy a Lanthorne:
Bespeake my sconce, tis ready hornd and all.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not yet, but Ile take order that it shall.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And are yee parted?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What a question's that?
Shall I weare crackt rings, Diamonds with a flaw,
Ile carry coles and you wil, no hornes, I know the law.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Is this your griefe?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This is inough, to make
Patience turne, she that was the paterne,
To whose proportion all our courtly dames,
Cut out their actions, she to fall: a signe—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: More will fall shortly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Her shame—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Growes here, who euer broacht the wyne,
The butt stands here, my forehead bears the signe,

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It merrits none, the shame's nor yours nor his,
That foot's euen made that neuer treads a misse,
Beauty came first from Heauen, Prometheus,
Stole it to make proud women bewteous,
Now, stolne goods thriue not: women steale from men
Then blame not them to seeke their owne agen.
Kings haue for this bene felons, and tis prou'd,
He neuer was diuine that neuer lou'd.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I finde no law for this.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Custome you proue,
And what's more Auncient then to pilfer louet

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A quillet well applide.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Then bury griefe,
Yf this be fellonie, my self's a theife.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A nimble witte, iust of the length of mine.
But come my leidge, forget, it so will I,
Our infant griefs must be old men and die,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not whilst hir fault suruiues,
What newes with thee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I bring your honor comfortable newes,
Your sonne's return'd from Pisa,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A comes ill,
And yet I hope his blest arriue will kill
This monster griefe.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He is a toward Prince.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Toward inough, and yet most strangely wean'd
And wedded from this worlds societie.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A parlous youth, sharpe and sattyricall,
Would a but spend some study in the law,
A would proue a passing subtle Barrister.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ha's a quick wit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And a speakes Latin too,
Truely and so few Lawyers vse to doe.

div.stage: Enter Prince Polymetes with a Booke.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Health to this honour'd presence: passing good!

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Welcome sweet Prince.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Thanks: superpassing good!
But honord father, see how he proceedes:
Learning was first made pilot to the world,
And in the chaire of contemplation,
Many degrees aboue the turning cloudes
Held in his hand the nine-leaf'd marble booke,
Drawne full of siluer lines and golden Stars.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But Sonne?

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: But father, it was learnings place,
Till emptie outsides, shadowes daub'd with golde
Pluckt him downe headlong, then a lost his wits,
And euer since liues Zany to the world,
Turnes Pageant-Poet, toyler to the presse,
Makes himselfe cheape, detested, hist and stale,
To euerie bubble and dull Groome.
Who for his out-sides gawdie, will presume
To make poore wit a hackney to his pride.
And with blunt rowled Iestes spur-gall his side
Till his soule bleede, O, I am more then mad,
To see meere shadowes censure and controule,
The substance, worthier both in sence and soule

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Fie Polymetes, though the robe of learning,
Sit comely on a Prince, yet weane thy thoughts
From this strict contemplation, and embrace
Publique assemblies, knightly exercise.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: How's that? to sweare and giue the sudden stab?
Sell Lands to purchase fashions? O tis base!
Bought gentrie, should true-borne worth disgrace.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Practise to hunt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: No, some that vse that sport
Giu't ore, being scarce one haire the better for't.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then practise Reuels.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Reuels sprightly play,
Yet euerie yeare, some reuell all away.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: All these are triuiall: Prince, be a Lawyer:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Of all Land monsters, some that beare that name,
Might well be sparde, whose vultur Auarice
Deuours men liuing: they of all the rest,
Deale most with Angells, & yet proue least blest.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Wrong not the Law.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I cannot, tis diuine:
And ile compare it to a golden chaine,
That linkes the body of a common-wealth,
Into a firme and formall Vnion.
It holds the sword, with an impartiall hand,
Curbs in the raines of an vnruly land,
Tis twin'd to Iustice, and with holy zeale,
Rightly determines the poore mans appeale.
And those that are lawes true administers,
Are fathers to the wrong'd, heauen's Iusticers.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Fore-god tis true, right properties of the Law
But vnder fauour, and with due respect
Of that vnualued perle, and the professors,
Your selfe and such lacke-Latin Aduocates
Infect the heart, and doe their best to change
The true intent of sanctimonious law.
Turne Church yards Champions, and make the ground growne rancke with Grandsires flesh,
Beare corne to feed the Sonne.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Will this be suffer'd?
But Polymetes, in thy stay at Pisa,
When heardst thou of thy Sister?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Much to late,
The reason, with your patience ile relate.
Beautious Emilia, whome I neuer saw,
But in the Rhethorique of discoursiue tongues
In Sancta Monta, neighbour to Sardinia,
Where siluer Arno in her Christall bosome,
Courts the fresh bancks with many an amorous kisse.
My Sister (as the countrie custome claim'd)
With all the choycest virgins of the Land,
Met at the Temple, halfe a league remote,
From all resort of people, which was deck'd
With all the Reliques, and the choicest Iemmes,
Marcellis, Pisa, or Ligorne could yeeld.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What follow'd this rich preparation?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Whilst they securely tend their Orizons,
Three armed Gallies of the faithlesse Turkes,
At this aduantage set their men on shore,
Enterd the Temple, and prophande their shrines,
On the high Altar sacrifiz'd the Priests,
Disray'd the Temple of the golden robes,
Murder'd the matrons, rauished the Maides,
And dragging them by the disheueld haire,
Did with their rauish'd bodies fill their boates,
Amongst the rest, Emilia whome report
Cald by no name but onely beautifull,
Was rauish'd, slaine, or taken prisoner.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O Polymetes! thy discourse confounds,
Thou healst old hurts, yet giu'st vs deeper wounds,
But words are ayre, see our arm'd Gallies man'd,
And in them place as many of our Knights
As lou'd Emilia and their Soueraignes health.
Ile vnto Pisa, and till our returne,
Because our widowed Duke-dome shall not mourne.
Be thou her minion, and possesse her chaire,
Fill that with honour, t'will fill thee with care,
Vrgeno denialls, Genowaes a dew,
Wee leaue old greefes, and goe in quest of new.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Better and better, now my hopes are fit,
The Duke thus gone, what tongue so bold dares say
I wrong'd my wife?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: That dares Horatioes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou art my self, we both haue but one bosome
One tongue, one soule, two bodies & one heart.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know't my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Tis true, but let that passe,
Wee two are one.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know your honour's wise.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And I know thee
For no small foole, twa's simple pollicie,
And not without some counsel of the lawe,
That not withstanding my wiues neere allyance
Vnto the Duke, I purchac'd a diuorce.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What was the cause?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I tell thee, the moste wrong
Was this, my Auarice thought she liu'd too long.
I know one man hath coffind vp sixe wiues
Since she was mine, and by the poorest, purst
A brace of thousand pounds: still good in Law,
Men must be rich, by thrift our treasures rise,
Giue me the man's knaue rich, take you poore wise,
But close, cocke sure ile feed me fat with sport,
Gull all, foole all, why? I haue Law-tricks for't. Exit

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How Justice Slender glories in the plot,
Which to deceiue him, my full braine begot?
But to his wife, true vertue though disgrac'd,
Shee's now halfe woo'd because shee's thought vnchast
Her sexes credit, or discredit thriues
In th' outward shape and fashion of their liues,
and be a womans vertues nere so strong.
Her honour's weighed vpon discourses tongue.
Be her fame sullied, were her thoughts as bright
As Innocence, the world would count her light.
For though mongst women, moste are beautious,
They that please time are counted vertuous,
And in this hope, ile to the Countesse goe,
Shee's counted light, Loue grant I finde her so. Exit.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Welcome to Genea Madam, and to make a short cut of our long trauell, faith tell mee, how doe you feele your selfe since you came a shore?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Feele my selfe? why with my hands, what an idle question's that?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Then pray bee you better occupied in your answere: but Madam, doe you remember what a multitude of fishes we saw at Sea? and I doe wonder how they can all liue by one another.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Why foole, as men do on the Land, the great ones eate vp the little ones, but Ioculo, I am great, passing great, and readie to lye downe.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Doe Madam, and ile stand by and doe my good will to deliuer you.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Mans death of what?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Why of your Maiden-head Madam & if you please, or rather of the huge birth of knauerie y'are in trauell of.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: And insooth Ioculo at this time I stand in some need of a wittie Mid-wif: but may I trust thee?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p:
Aboue the girdle-stead, and below the knee Madam without any danger, why Madam, you know at our first meeting in the Turkes Gallies, where we were both prisoners, and in a manner strangers, I rested faithful when we counterfeited ourselues lunaticke to escape their furie I proued not false when wee were cast naked a shore: I stood firme to you, and neuer since left your companye: now hauing had these tryals of me abroade, neuer
mistrust my secrecie at home.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I wil credit thee, and now receiue this embrion of knauerie, brieflie as I deliuer it. I vnderstand since our priuate arriuall heere at Genoa, that the Duke my father hearing of my surprisal from Monta sancta, attended with a hundred Knights, is gone to seeke a needle in a bottle of Hay.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Or rather to catch a quicke Eele by the—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Teeth, as I haue done you sir?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Nay, and you breake iestes a my teeth once, I haue done with you.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: If the breaking of the iest kept your teeth whole, twas well broken: but to the purpose; as well to trie what mettle our Genowaies wits are made of, as also to put my Brothers humor to the test, I intend to dance a prettie change with my name (for by nothing else I am sure they can knowe me, being in my infancie carried to my Aunts at Pisa) then insteed of Emilia, call me Tristella.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Agreed, but what man i'th mist is this?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I know not yet, lets walke, and take occasion to confer with them.

div.stage: Enter Polymetes reading, end Inlis taking Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Yet keep without eye-shot so long as you can

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: O moste Diuine!

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Tobacco? the best in Europe, 't cost mee ten Crownes an ounce by this vapor.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Art not asham'd?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Of your foppish humor? yes by this Element villanously asham'd, pox on't, leaue it, you are a scholler, goe but to antiquitie, reade the Chronicles, you may finde some of your Ancestors chronicled for winning a Wenches fauour for loosing their armour, but few for wit and Schollership: Souldiers &
Scollers could neuer set their horses together, especially in this kicking age: but who comes heere? one she-Satyre or other to pitch vp her Tent, cast downe her gauntlet and proclaime thee coward for not stabbing her, when shee gaue thee the moste plaine apparant and open lye.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Ioculo, we are fallen into their eyes.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Theile hardly see their way then, for we are shrew'd moats, but als one, ile giue occasion of quarreil, answert you as you can,

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Your reason Sir?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: To make thee recoile, or with the Souldier to fall off, i'st your countrie manner to corriue a leader, being vpon or before present seruice as I am?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, I did not see your charge.
Would I had neuer seene her, for her eye
Hath set my thoughts in a strange mutenie.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What, in loue Iulio?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: No Prince, loue's in me,
I like a slaue indure loues tyrannie.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Madam, your Brother.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Slaue to all slaues be he that snares his eye,
In a weake Syrens Cob-web flatterie.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: God saue faire sweete.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Amen, from such as you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: You had said for such, had your tongue gone true.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Why then belike I lye.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I would you did, within my Curtens.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Marry loue forbid.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Nay, loue is willing, for he cries lets goe:

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then loue hath two tunges, for he tels me no,
so pray let's part.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: What, and our lips not meete?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Now fie vpon't, like Broom-men in the street?
Y'are a young wooer, or else much to rude,
To shew this kindnesse fore a multitude,
But by the blush that colours ore your face,
You would scarce doo't in a more priuate place.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: This same strange thing i'th likenes of a woman,
Tastes of much wit, though I not loue her sex,
Ile arme my thoughts to cracke a iest with her.
What, graueld lulio?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No, but run a Land:
Is your wits shipping any better mand?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, will you board it?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: No, I dare not venter:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Make but a shot in iest and you may enter.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: You are a Scholler.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I haue seene some Schooles.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: You came not ore i' the last fleet of Fooles.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You tooke my roome vp.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I pray tak't agen,
Weele haue no women fooles saile amongst men.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Your wit's much currish.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why 't bites not you,
It feedes on fooles flesh, so wisemen adieu

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Please you accept the curtsie of the towne?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I need not, I haue curtsies of mine ownes
ther's one for you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How chance your wit's so free?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Onely to out-goe Iadish company.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Here are none such.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Take heede, for if you tire,
Sheele keepe her pace and leaue you in the mire.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A womans feature, but a Schollers tongue
In quick discourse, Philosophers nere wondred
More at the strange conception of the windes,
Then I admire how she attain'd this wit:
Did not true learning make the soule diuine,
She hath spoke enough to make me conuertine.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: My loues are sound, & wait but your reply,
A short lin'd accent, either no or I.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I am not too seueare, nor yet so kinde,
To fall for euerie idle puff of winde.
But farwell, ile take counsell of my pillow,
Pittie fresh youth should wither in greene willowe.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Appoint the place sweete, ile not misse mine houte.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: At the three fooles.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Ile meete.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: And make vp foure.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sweet wordes, kinde lookes, what? and a parting kisse.
Words, lookes and lips crie all, the wenche is his.
I am possest deuill, loue perswades my minde,
That if to him, to me shee'le proue more kinde.
What's Iulio made of? hadst thou soule or sence,
Thou wouldst not prentise thy affections,
Nor tie thy fortunes to a strangers loue.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: A little liking my Lord, a ierk a trick or so, but no pure loue I protest, but be impartiall, cast of the furd-gowne of hate, and speake out of the naked Doublet and hose of iudgement: is she not worthy to be beloued? nay, might not she and I liue passing well together?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, if to liue in bondage be no hell,
I thinke you two, might doe exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Well my Lord, because ile bee no example of selfe-will, ile breake off our meeting at the three Fooles, and send for her to Court, where ile put al my loue into one quart of Maligo, & your melancholly humor into another, and he that hath done last, shall for penance giue her a kicke a the lips, and a pipe of Tobacco be my witnesse, that's all the loue I beare her.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well Iulio,
How ere you iuggle, if you doe agree,
You must be pleas'd to weare the keepers fee. Exennt

div.head: Actus Secundus.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Sir, I doe not loue to double with a woman if my friend, much lesse with you my most vpright & straight Count, my yong Lord (as I told you) is turnd absolute prodigall.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: How prodigall?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Marry thus prodigall, to frequent ordinaries is his ordinarie practise, rubs out whole weekes together in bowling. Allyes, bandies away his pocket full of French-Crownes in a morning, and counts it a prettie sport to procure heate.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou telst me wonders, he that but last day,
Was neuer seene to walke without a booke,
Writ against pleasure, and make bitter iests
Of honest recreation, turn'd dissolute,
I see no reason for't, the law and I,
(I tell you plainely Adam) thinke you lye.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Thinke as you will sir, there's not a tricke vsde in the towne that deserues damnation, but hee desires to deale in't, tis pitty a was not made a tradesman, he loves to follow his occupation a life, & that which makes him doubt most, he is in loue with the Indian punck Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Punke! how the foole that doth not know it slaunders a leafe, nick-names a stranger herb.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: No herb a grace I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nor good thrift neither,
Yet there's one dunce, a kinde of plodding Poet,
Sweare's twas not in the first creation,
Because he findes no ballad argument,
To proue old Adam a Tobacconiste,

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p:
I thinke none a the name lout's it,
I haue heard olde Adam was an honest man, and a good Gardiner lou'd Lettice well, Sallets and Cabbage reasonable well, yet no Tobacco: Again, Adam Bell a substantial out-law, & passing a good Archer, yet no Tobaconist. Further, Diogenes, whose propper name might bee Adam for ought I know, lou'd Carretts well, Leeke porredge, passing well, yet no Tobacco: to conclude, my great Grandfathers Grandfathers father, and my selfe all Gardners, yet could not abide this Chimney-sweeper Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: They did not: take me with you, what's the, cause They were al plaine folks, & did not know the lawes.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.p: They were plaine indeede, and thereof grew the prouer be, plaine dealing is a Iewell.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: But he that vseth it shall die a begger.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: That addition was made by some Lawyer or Poet, to auoid which, they cannot indure plaine-dealing should haue a hand in any of their actions.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Touch no mans function, there are ierks & tricks
Spurne not the law, for if you doe, it kicks.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: So will a spur-gald Iade sir, but to all these misdemeanors, a maintaines a priuate punck, one Tristella that hee had in way of reuersion from Iulio, a twindger, a meere Horsleach, one that will suck out the braines of his treasurie, and make a meere skin of his wealth, I, out of my Loue reprehended his error, and he in a furie kick't me out of dores, and discharged me of his seruice.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I like not this, tis neither right nor streight done with no law-trick, nor no good conceite, but here a comes.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: With Autumne in his bosome, pray God she shake not downe his leaues, and leaue him to make the Duke his father a bald reckoning.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Peace and obserue.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Though I be a stranger to you,
Yet am I well acquainted with your humor.
A Lady cannot liue about the Court
Without the enuie of your Epigrams,
If she be pleasant, she is counted light,
If ruddy, painted, if her ruffes be thicke,
They aske much poaking.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Trust me, loue hath kild
That worme-wood humor, bring th'authoritie
Of one true tongue to proue my poesse,
Euer wrong'd woman.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: And you'l doo't agen?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: That's a good wench.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I pray who ought that pen?
That in a stammering Iambick vaine,
Glanc'd at Emiliaes loose and gaudie traine.
And broke broad iests vpon her narrow heele,
Poak't her Rebatoes, and suruaid her steele,
tide her fring'd garters, bought her words by weight

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Still good in law, and an vpright conceit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Doe you not know that man?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Suppose I doe?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You did but flout them, and youle flout me too
You wondred not Cornelia being so faire,
Would be beholding to her Laundresse dresse haire.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I know not this.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: True, nor that Florymell,
Became a Pages habit passing well,
Vsde single Rapier, tooke the rouse and swore,
Of all land Beasts she could not brooke the Bore,
Nor that Count Lurdo, comming to a fray,
Brought not the worth of one poore haire away.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: More then his owne.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That iest comes neere to me,
Tis our-growne now, a wants authoritie.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Nor that Melina whom your Muse renownes
Wore out as many suiters as new gownes.
And the same day that she was marryed,
Vpon her finger wore her maiden-head.
In likenes of a Dyamond.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Indeede twa's sed,
That for Ring Melina sold her head.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: But y'are all Ouids.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: They are bawdie mates,
Touch Lawyers too, indeed abuse all states,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Poets are wanton, and no doubt inioy,
Their faire Corynnaes, though perhaps lesse coy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Suppose some doe?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Each one in this agrees to scandall vs.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: And talke of Lawyers fees.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Graunt me but loue, & with my vtmost power,
I will defend your sexes stainlesse honour:
And with my pen dipt in the iuice of gall,
Be his soules terror, that hereafter shall,
Cast ynke at honours garments, or aspire
To name your sex with an vnhallowed fire.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I take your word.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: Then seale it with a kisse.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: That kisse my Lord deserues an Epigram.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sit downe good Vncle.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: An vnbidden guest
Should bring a stoole along.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: A womans iest.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: You meane a lye, for women vse to lye.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: But not like Schollers by authoritie.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yet they may produce lying authoritie, and so cannot Poets,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Nor Lawyers neither.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Are you a Lawyer?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ifaith Madam, he hath sit on the skirts of law any time this thirtie yeares.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p:
Then he should bee a good Trencher-man by
his profession.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Your reason Adam.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: I knew one of that facultie in one terme eate vp a hole Towne, Church, Steeple and all.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: I wonder the Bels rung not all in his belly.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: No sir, he solde them to buy his wife a Taffety
Gowne, and himselfe a veluet Iacket.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: What a prou'd Iacke was that? but I wonder at Lawyers for one thing, many of them vse to take their fees afore-hand.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: For a two-folde pollicy, one is they were commonly greedie, the other for feare if their Clyents follow their Counsell long, they will not be worth a fee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Tis well said Lady, you doe well to iest with an olde man.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: A saies true, for if you shold iest too much with a young man, it might proue earnest, & so the fruites of your ieasts make you both a sham'd on't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well said Adam, but leauing at a full iest, Vncle, what earnest businesse brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Your honours sudden Metamorphosis,
Tolde by your trustie Seruant, and confirmd
By publique rumor.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why what saies Goody Fame, and my trustie Seruant

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This is the worst my Lord that you expend
Your treasure on that Ladies maintenance.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: S'foot say I doe, what, has the worme-eaten bawd Fame: or ere a pander-like foole else to doe with it? giue her maintenance, why she is of my nere affinitie, should I see my shee affinitie goe in tatters? I allow my Seruant rags, & I were worse then a Iew, if I should suffer my shee affinitie to goe naked.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Law takes your part, & if your pursse grow short
Rather then spend the publique treasurie,
Ile lend your Grace a brace of thousand pounds,
Prouided this, that as our Booke-men write
I haue securitie.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A Lawyer right?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Securitie? Leases and old rents, Castle and Towne-ships, able men, good securitie, Townes are no Starters, theile hold out winde and weather.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I craue no more, let me haue pawnes and vse.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How? Lords turne Vsurers? those that should
punnish broke age deale vppon pawnes?
If it were once his owne,
Hee'de lend him mony on his Duke-domes crowne

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: But faith Vncle tell me, what think you of this
Lady? would she not make a prettie peart Dutches?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Shee's faire, nor do I discommend your choise
I wish her your's, a priuate friend or so,
I know mad Ierks, and know that Lawe allowes,
Princes their priuate pleasures, and my selfe
Will doe my best to gaine your honours loue,
I will not absolutely say there are,
But there may be, if so your honour please,
Sellers and Vaults, which from your priuate Garden
May vnder ground lead to your bed-chamber.
Whither, I will not name my selfe, but some close friend,
May vnsuspected bring your beautious Lady.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Lord what a broaking Aduocate is this?
He was some Squiers Scriuenor, and hath scrapt
Gentilitie out of Atturneys fees:
His bastard actions proue him such a one,
For true worth scornes to turne Camelion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Madam, my Vncle out of tender-loue,
Better to shun all scandalous suspect,
That might attend on our vnsuiting Iodes
Will lodge you at his house, whither at times—

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Your Grace may haue accesse.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Tis so indeede.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Is there a backe way?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And a priuate doore,
A secret vault, and twentie odde tricks more.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A Stoue?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And Arbors with sweete violet Beds,
That haue bin prest to death with maiden-heads,
Where you may sport and breath, and take a rouse

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Pe, this Lawyer keepes a bawdie house,
I shall be ready to deceiue you all.
My Lord, your Law-plot's, most iudiciall.

div.p: Bnt who comes heere? some one of your cast clyents.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Gods me, the Countesse.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mum, I cannot stay,
There's a clowd rising, driues my Sun away.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Is this your wife?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Madam, tis she that was.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: That was and is not? how comes that to passe?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I cannot tell, God & his conscience knowes

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And the world sees Colossus on my browes,
Hercules Pillers, here's non vltra writ.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Not in brasse Characters?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No, hornes more fit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Hath not the Lawe diuorc'd and made a bar twixt our affections? wert not thou content to take a pention?

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.p: Which you still detaine.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Good wit, Law-trickes and firme, you may complaine.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Complaine I doe, I kneele before the throane and sue for Iustice, but yet can purchase none.
Complaine I doe Cousen.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: O, as you are a Prince, and you a virgin.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I was one long since,
This is no place for passion, drie your eyes,

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Greife nailes me to the ground, I cannot rise,
Ile grow immodest, iustice is exild,
And so shall duetie, patience turne wilde,

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Come, leaue the Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Doe, for wit and Law knowe shee's a foole,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A couple quoth Iack-daw.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Who calles?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: In passion Lady.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Discontent or so.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Be not, be counsaild, do not let dispaire,
Like the ranke cancker bred by sultrie aire.
Eate this young Rose of beautie in the bud:
But in the Aprill Sunne of youthfull blood
Let the sweet blossome ripen, thriue and grow,
To those full ioyes which none but Louers know.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: The man talkes idely, tell me I am faire,
Louely and young.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You are, by loue you are,
Not faire, you are: Leanders paramour:
Compar'd with you was a swarth Blackamour
Your haire is softer then the Colchean Fleece,
Your well lim'd features, natures maister peece
Your eyes too Dyamonds, set in purer molde
Then rocks of currall, or the Indian gold.
In thy smooth chin there is an Iuorie pit,
Where blushing Venus and young Cupid sit,
Feathering of golden shafts, the wounding heads,
Made of thy amber tresses finest threds.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: You will not buy me sure you praise me so.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Yet faire, ile bid faire for you ere I goe,

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: He that bids faire for me deceiues his eye.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: By heauen a doth not.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Wilfull periurie, what meanes all this?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This my discourse intends,
Were husbands Saints, some wiues would haue close friends.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Some bad perhaps, but—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Husbands but for't, true, woot? prethee woot thou?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Vd's Hartlings doe?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Doe what?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Loue-tricks quickly, woo't thou prethee.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: No, I prize my credit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Credit? life a man,
What talks of credit? art not knowne a strumpet?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: You doe me wrong.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Damnation, what a glosse,
This gilded copper, Diamond of glasse,
What strang shew it makes? ile giue you a color
Your face was nere worse painted, then ile paint
Your Wain-scot credit, you are a priuate bit,
Kept for some great made Diues. Red hot scandall
Suck the natiue coulour of your soules
As it hath scorch'd thy credit, shriueld Baw'd,
Spunge, Lemon-pill, and more irrelishable
Then ore-dride Stock-fish, fie.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Vpon thy shame.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thy husband, O thy husbands bow-leg'd fame
Death I shall hate thee.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: O for honour doe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Sweare thou art my strumpet.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Ile indure that to.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Shalt not deny't, hart, canst not.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Yes, I can.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Doo't for thy life, thy soule, basse curtezan.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Farwell, if friendship be at such a rate,
Before ile purchast, ile liue still in hate.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Hart, a new fashion,
A Lady poore, beautifull and chast? cleane
From the bias of Custome: to be poore, painted,
And proud is as common in Genoa, as felt and feather
In the fortunate Iland: but chast and poore,
As singuler and rare, as Conscience with the Anabaptist.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Come hether Boy, didst neuer owe me seruice

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Yes Madam, more then euer I paid you honestly, and were a not my Maister.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Thy Maister, who?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Horatio, he that puts chastetie to the quick, & honor to the stab, but ile shew him the nature of a right French-man, deny him homage, for sweare allegiance, and come behinde hand in cash keeping, & with his owne pursse maintaine you against him.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Thy purpose brieflie.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: In balde sentences, your noted wrongs are pittied.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Pittyed, by whome?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: By me, lodgings prepar'd and dyet, which I humbly tender your honor, as first paiment of the ancient debt, my seruice owes you.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: But is the lodging priuate?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: At mine owne mothers, and though I say't, she keepes an honest house, though my father bee a Cittizen.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Of what profession?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Neither foole nor Phisitian, but an ingenious Pothecarie.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: And what resort?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p:
Verie ciuil and moste quiet resort, patients, the
house is set round with patients twice or thrice a day, and because theile be sure not to want drinke, euerie one brings his owne water in an Vrinall with him.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Doth a vse phisicke too? that's beyond his warrant.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: O Lord Madam, better men then hee straine curtesie with their warrants in this age, besides, you being musicall, shall meet much content, for my mother lodges three or foure Knights & Ladies Daughters that practise musicke and needle-work, and wil no doubt be exceeding proud of your company, wilt please you walke?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Thou art the Star, by whome my fate is led, My shame's so publique, ide faine hide my head.

div.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: CVrrant in Law, & how encountred you. Wiu. Ile tell you my good Lord (I thank my bringing vp, I can talke, I vse not to haue my tongue to seeke when it should pleasure anye man, especially my good Lord) I tolde her what a credit it was to haue a man of great credit, & that which is more, a skilfull Lawyer that can stand out in her case at a dead life, and one that if need were, could make a crazy action sound, I put her in minde what it was to haue such a one to her sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou speakst but right, for so I am indeede.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: You are, I vrg'd it, and she confest to me that the verie first night shee saw you she dream't on you, and wisht you in her bed, and her bed in the midst of the Riuer.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How, ith the Riuer?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Yes for sooth,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the middle of the tide.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Yes in her dreame.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Good,
But she doth loue me.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Beleeue it my Lord she doth, marrie you must thinke I drew her and drew her, and wrought her and wrought her, till I made her as plyant and, tractable table as wax, marrie with all, she is as constant as Lucretia, and will not for a thousand pounds, till shee hath the law of her side.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: I sound her meaning, first ile gull my Nephew.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Her intent right, she intends to make a Gull of the Prince, and an absolute Goose of you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Still good in Law, ile fetch him ore of all,
Get all, pursse all, and be possest of all,
And then conclude the match, marrie at least,
When can you tell? Ile vse her as a hand
To picke the Princes coffers, and for reward
To prison, marrie her, for tricks can doo't, (actions.
The worlds squint-eyd, and dares not prie into our
Here lyes her walke (my Lute Win) she shall see,
Youthe's leaden footed in respect of me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Win, prethee giue the Fidler a testar and fend him packing, what a scraping the tongue keepes? doe's a thinke the Count keeps a Tauerne or a Bawdie-house? my good Lord! beseech your honour pardon me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: No harme sweet Loue, how dost thou like this Caper?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Passing wel my Lord, wil you neuer leaue these coltish tricks? but to the matter: I sent you my resolution by your Maid, haue you receiu'd it.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I haue, and it holds currant,
Then tender me possession.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Of thy chast loue.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Not too much hast for that, you haue a wife.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I had one.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And still haue.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Thy loue shall quickly wed her to her graue, I nere did loue her.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: When she was a maide
You swore you did, how soon poore youth's betraid
To helplesse ruine: doe you loue me?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I faith.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: For how long?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Till death.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O deadly lye.
Ile tell you iust how long, loue's bred i'th blood,
Prospers as long as beauties in the bud.
When beautie withers, lustfull loue growes colde,
And ere it be halfe ripe, tis rotten old.
If you haue me, you must not put on yellowes,
Ile haue my selfe, my servant and my fellowes.
My loue, my liking, and a second me,
I loue to rellish sweet varietie:
Your old wife mou'd you, I shall vex you more.
Take Coach with Gallants euen a sore your dore.
Take Rings, giue bracelets wouen of my haire,
Which to spight you, my Seruants arme shall weare.
Ile in your presence sit vppon his knee,
Exchanging kisses if you speake to me.
Ile pont in scorne, crie mew, and looke aside,
At which, if you but frowne, ile roundly chide,
I am not as I seeme, dissembling wit
Is my best meanes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Square to my humour fit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I was a Beggar borne.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And so was I.

sp.speaker: Em
sp.l: Traded in lust and gainefull brothelrie.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The fitter for my turne, I was a man
Borne to no hopes, but a few shreds of witt
A Grammer Scholler, then a Scriuenor.
Dealing for priuate vse twixt man and man,
and by close broake age set them at debate:
Incenst them vnto Law, which to maintaine,
I lent them money vpon Lands and Plate,
After the rate of seauen-score in the hundred.
Then did I learne to countefeit mens hands,
Noble-mens armes, interline Euidences,
Make false conueyances, yet with a trick,
Close and cock-sure, I cony-catch'd the world.
Hauing scrap'd prettie wealth, I fell in League
With my first wife, and (though I say't my selfe)
She had good dooings, her backe commings in
And priuate goings out, rais'd me aloft:
I followed cases of the law abroad,
and she was merrie with her friends at home.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Did you nere take her kissing?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Twentie times.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Were you not Iealious?

sp.speaker: Lur
sp.l: Neuer nothing lesse.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Yet saw her kisse with Strangers.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Kisse and play.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And were you a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Cuckold by this light.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What? a wittall.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And a Wittall too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And knew't?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And knew't.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And sufferd it.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: It went attirde in golde, a golden Crest,
Is a braue fashion, and accounted best.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.l: Madam, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What newes?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: The Prince.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The Prince.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And Iulio.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Which way?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: From thence.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: That way the vault, from thence the priuate dore, as I stood Centinell at the further end of the Vault, they being vnacquainted with the turnings, came groping and feeling, as commonly men wil do especially in a strange place, and as I am true sinner, had I not spyed the Diamond on his finger (twinne, to this a my conscience) they had beene vpon me in the darke ere I had bene aware of them.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The Prince.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And Iulio.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Quick away.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What plot?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Behinde the Arras? scapt behinde the Arras.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Behinde the Arras.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Close, cocke, sure, be wise,
They onely thriue that best can temporize.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: A rare vault by this light, and neuer deuis'd without the aduice of a grand Iurie of Bawdes, a word with your lips Tris.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: As god mend me Prince you smell bawdie.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Since I came into thy company Win. And how ist Tris? fore-God a prettie lodging.

sp.speaker: Inl.
sp.l: And verie faire hangings.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Passing good workman-ship, what storie is this Tris?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Why my Lord? the Poeticall fiction of Venus kissing Adonis in the violet bed.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Fore-god tis true, and marke where the Cuckoldly knaue Vulcan stands sneaking behinde the
brake bush to watch a'm.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: A prettie conceit Iulio, doost see Vulcan with the horning parenthesis in his fore-head! I hit indirectly vpon the leaft pap at three passes for a hundred Crownes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not for a hundred.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ist a match?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Tis done, where will you take your stand?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Here, any where, hart has the Arras an ague, it trembles so?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No, Vulcans fearefull.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And with a feare it comes, haue at the Cuckkold.

sp.speaker: Lnr.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Harke, the Arras is in labour.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Mas I heard something groane.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Ile be the Mid-wife and helpe to deliuer it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Sweet Prince.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Harke Wench, I smell Bores grease.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Will you but heare me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now excuse what tricke? She whispers to him.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How? but a Picture? ile trie that presently,
If you loue me, disfigure it not, I esteeme it onely for
the liuely workmanship.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then let me haue a sight on't.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Vpon condition youle neither deface it with weapon, nor soile it with your breath—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: On my Virginities maiden-head wee will not discouer Lurdo behinde the Arras.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hart a the Deuill, your Vncle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O forbeare, fore God passing good workman indeede.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Marke but the glance of his eye.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The hanging of his neither lip.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The blush of his cheeke.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: The curle of his haire.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The pit of a chin.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What a smooth hand a hath?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Long fingers like a Lady.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Not so much but a seale Ring.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Armes and all, viz a tame Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: And the foole swallowes it rarely, & you marke him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is the numbe Asse insensible of Scoffes?
Ile touch him neerer, yet mine eye deceiues me,
And this be not Count Lurdoes counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You may soone know that my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: As How?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If it be his, a hath the Gowte in his left foote,

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: The verie same, his shoe is cut and all, Farwell Tris, and yet ile startle him a little better afore we leaue him, fore-god tis so like him, I doubt, wether it be the shadow or his substance.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A blocke.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: A shadow.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: A meere sencelesse stone.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then tis a counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: An absolute counterfeit, what doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Marrie many Counterfeits walke in the likenesse of good mony, and so may this doe, which to preuent ile naile him to a poast, for feare a passe currant on your lips in my absence, and so deceiue me?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Ile sweare a shall not, gentle Prince be short,
Length kils the heart of the moste feeling sport.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well Maiden, I am content, this iest shall repriue your head for this once, but beware the next encounter, come Ariadnes clew, will you vnwinde, and light vs through this vault of darkenesse, and theres your Naulum.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p:
Thanke you my Lord, and your businesse stand this way at midnight, ile let you in by this token, and take this from me, when you come againe, bring the
Lady a Diamond, or some prettie & foolish stone, for I can tel you these same paultrie stones are in high request amongst Ladies, especially such old mowsers as I haue beene in my time, & as I say when you come, be not asham'd to knock, and if I come not knocke lustely, and again, and neuer giue ouer knocking till you heare my hem, did you neuer know Wins hem?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Why hast thou a priuate hem?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Haue I? Ifaith sir I, few Gallants ith town that are of any standing at all, but are acquainted with my hem, but come close my Lord, close, & be sure the next time you come you doe not forget to knock lustily,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My Loue, my life, oh thou art made
Out of the soule of wit, and thy conceits,
Of the best fashion.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Did you taste the iest?

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.l: Diuinely, oh diuinely, tart and quick,
Pleasing, yet not teadious I was wrapt

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: In a knaues skin.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My sences were entranc'd.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Into a fooles Paradice.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Oh my sweet Phoenix, out of thy ashes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Is your loue so hot, you meane to burne me?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Oh fit honnyed me,
And then their numnesse, didst thou neuer reade
Of any Lawyer came to be Duke?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Neuer, but I haue heard of a Cuckold that was an Vsurper.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why such a one would I be.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What, a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes, and an Vsurper too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: So you are for you Lawyers vsurpe more crowns then halfe a Countrie.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Vlisses, Tully, Lawyers, but no Dukes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Menelaus and Vulcan were Cuckolds but no Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Fore-mee tis true, but now I doe remember nought to that purpose:

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The most lustfull Goates
Weare guilded hornes, and goe in Veluet Coates.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What newes Win?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Faith ordinarie houshold newes, yonders a wel-fac'd Gentleman craues a may change a word with you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: His name?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Horatio.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Leaue vs to confer.
A trustie friends, the soules high Treasurer.

div.p: In dumps Horatio? what, my second selfe clowded with passion?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: O my honor'd Lord, Our soules and our affections are made all of one fashion now the slightest wrong that scars the reputation of my friend, stabs daggers to my heart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I know it true, and I can proou't,
Our loues are twinnes,
But to the wrong, dares any idle tongue
Barke at our greatnes?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Their names?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My wife? the manner?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Mongst her lustfull Mates,
She shame's not to giue out, that by your greatnesse,
knowledge, credit, and friends in highest place,
You haue diuorc'd her without due desert.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: We must demurre of this, ile haue a tricke
By way of Habeas Corpus to remoue
This talking Gossip, come Horatio,
Some proiect, how? what course for her remoue:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I cannot counsell, but fore-god my Lord,
My lodgings mightily annoy'd with rats,
That eate my papers and deface my books
How should I rid them.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Easily, poison them,
And well remembred, this she Rat my wife,
That eates and teares the leaues of my repute,
Shall taste like speeding Phisicke in thine eare,
Canst temper poison?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And kill a Rat.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That she shall neuer swell on't.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mum for that,
This she Rat is a Deuill.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A Limbe of Sathan.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Enuy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Destruction.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mallice.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ratsbane doo't?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Ere my disgrace get age, rare tricks and I will foole the world, woo't, doo't?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Rate shall die.

div.stage: Enter Countesse, three or foure young Gentlewomen, sowing by an houre-glasse.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Quick prettie Damsels, that your task were done The fore-noones eldest minutes almost runne.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Then the glasse runs to fast.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: I thinke not so,
Hadst thou my cares, thoudst think it ran too slow.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: I haue my taske forsooth.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: So haue not I.
Yet with these sands my sorrowes run away
I turne them with the glasse, the glasse is run,
Yet my hudge masse of cares is scarse begun,
Here's a fault, little one what worke make you.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: True stitch forsooth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Then see you worke it true.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: Pray madam teach me to take out this knot Of hearts ease.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Hearts ease, I haue almost forgot,
I could haue wrought it well when I was young:
But in good sadnesse, I haue had none long.
What's that?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: A branch of Rue.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: A comon weede, of all herbes else I worke that well indeede, how chance your flower is behinde the glasse?

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Indeede Ile get it vp:

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Indeede alas.
I cannot chide with her, yet tyrant care,
At my intreate will not one sight forbeare:

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Why sigh you madam?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Oh I greeue to see,
Youth run to cath at their owne misery.
You are like Aprill or Rose buds in May,
You neuer wither, till the wedding day,
Euen so did I, so pretty soules will you,
Youth wears mild Hearts ease, marriage bitter Rue.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Be not so sad, good madam, do b ut smile,
Weele haue a song sad sorrow to beguille.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Saue you faire Ladies, madam, my businesse leads me to you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: If in your antient suite,
My cares are deafned and my vtterance mute.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Your eare, be wood, what shold beget this coynes
Were I a stranger, or some Citty Gull
I would comend thee, but I know the worlde.
Lodging is costly, maintenance askes charge:
Thou art diuorc'd and hast no other helpe,
But thy bare comings in: accept my Loue,
I will allow thee twenty pound a quarter.
To buy thee Pinnes.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Leaue this ymodest suite.
Or by my honor—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come, these words of course
My fame, myne honor, and my deare respect:
Are but like Ignes fatui to delude,
Greene and vnseason'd wits, pry thee be kinde,
A guilded slip carryes as faire a show,
As perfect gold, guilt honor may do so

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: But put your slip to triall, the slight gold,
Is soone rubd of:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come, thy distinctions solde
Let not thy Aprill bewty like a Rose,
Fade in the bud, and ripened pleasures lose,
My sword thy honor: thy estate my purse,
Shall man and strenghten,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I detest that course.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your husband hath a sweete heart:

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: For his ill.
Shall I turne traitor & myne own fame kill?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Tis dead already, euery idle tongue, Stabs it to death.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I haue the greater wrong.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Thou wrongst thy selfe & spurnst thy proper good
Am I not youthfull see my wanton blood
Daunceth within my vaines, and blushing, Courts
Thy generous bewty to more amorous sports,
You shall not choose.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: hands of.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I loue the e deere.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I hate thee deadly.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Doost thou?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Shall I sweare?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No, ile beleeue thee Phoenix of thy sex,
I glorie in thy vertues, and reueale,
What by my oath I promisd to conceale.
Your iealious husband vrgde me to this try all,
Pawning his oath vpon your strict deny all,
all bastard Iealosie should be exilde,
and antient loue entirely reconsilde.
I touch'd your heart, and now I finde it true,
Ile giue you notice, ile impoison you.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Thou speak'st all comfort.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I was made of hope. and rich perfourmance waits vpon my words.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Father of my faire fortunes, whose rich loue begets this reuniting couenant,
sp.l: When comes this long expected sealing day?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To morrow, the houre eight.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Certaine?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As life.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Then follow mee to feast,
Thy newes Horatio is the Welcomest guest.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Swell heart, hold bosom, yeeld not to relent,
and yet her beautie, colourable trash,
Her vertues, vengeance Hypocriticall,
I loue her, furie, poison, Hidraes gall,
Impatience man me, blacke damnation
Vsher my practice, poyson play thy part,
and doe my latest greetings to her heart.
We all must downe, yet here the difference lyes.
Many for sins, she for her vertue dyes.

div.head: Actus Quartus.
div.stage: Enter Polymetes Julio, Horatio, Emilia & Pages

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: T Tristella.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
Good wine needes no bush, nor a good face
paynting thou art fauour of thy selfe, and what thou cost is not vnder a colour.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I know no other paynter but one, and her name is modestie, and she sometimes throwes a blush into my face to make my pale cheeks red, but els you shall neuer take mee for an Aldermans poast.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Why an Aldermans poet?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Marke but where great poasts are newly painted, you shall see much egresse & regresse in and out, & where you see a face newly okered, tis a signe ther's great traffique, & much stirring to and fro.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Come sit, sit, nay neerer, neerer, neerer yet.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then I shall sit vpon your skirts.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Iulio and Horatio, what shal's haue to supper?
I am now in the spending vayne.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then God for mee: what make I so neare?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Good action, you shall not remooue, I learnt that phrase of myne vncle, boy, know what Adam hath bespoken for our palates.
sp.l: Where there a banquet to be had,
More rate and deere, then that Vitellius made:
It shoulde be seru'd in, but Horatio,
What shal wee eate that's costly, and that's rare?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: A roated Phoenix were excellent good for that Lady.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And why for that Ladye.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Fare ech'd and deere bought, is good for you know who

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: For Ladyes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I for Ladyes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Then the most cheape stuffe, and next to hand is good for you know who.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: For knaues.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I for knaues.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Adam what haue you ready.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Sir you may haue a Calues head.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: here's a Gentleman hath one in his hat already, no more. Calues head I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Hast any Pheasants or Partriges?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: No, but if your Lord-shipe will haue a dish of Woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: No for God-sake, they are the stalest meate with me of any, for I neuer sit to meate with these gallants, but there's Woodcocks cleane through the table.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Then vnlesse you will haue a Dotrell or a Gull.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A Gull? why which of these Gent. woot thou serue in? do you not heare how Adam flouts you?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: I meane a Sea-gull bakt.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I in any case lets haue that, I haue fed my wit on many a land-Gull, once let mee banquet my selfe of a Sea-gull, some Sea Captain, I lay my life that has a desire to sup with mee, but such as thou hast, I prithee be briefe

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Lay the table in the with-drawing roome.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: I will sir, your honor can haue no Larks Ile assure you.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Two Citizens sonnes and a Poet bought vp all ith towne, flung away the bodies onely to haue a pye made of the braines.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: A signe either they lackd braines, or else they did it because they would beare a braine.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: T was tolde me that the young Lord Polymetes Was entred here.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: He that so tolde thee fellow tolde thee true.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I cry your Lordship mercy, let this letter
Supply th'vnwilling office of my tongue,
And be the sad reporter of my newes.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.l: What ominous news can Polimetes daunt?
Haue we not Hyren heere?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ouid not all thy Metam Metamorphosis
Can shew such transformation, oh my God!
It is not possible, (is this my sonne?)
A has mistooke himselfe, my life a has,
For the seauen liberall sciences; a reades,
The seauen blacke deadly finnes.
Must you needes sonne turne ouer these linnen leaues
hauing such store of paper? this is miraculous.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Newes, newes my hearts will make your iocund soules daunce in your bosomes, now which ioyfull tongue amongst you all cries first God saue the Duke? God saue Duke Polymetes.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The newes is not so happy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Tush looke here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My Lord I'me sorry for your heauinesse.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Thou shouldst haue said so to a Porter that's heauy loaden.
But come, sit, sit in councell, let's deuize
How to spend all this countlesse masse of wealth,
My father hath bequeath'd mee at his death,
Quite from the popular and vulgar garbe,
We will be ode in all things, and retaine
No common humor in our large expence.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: An honorable minde, and were your father
A liue to note these hopefull parts in you,
How would it moue him and surprize his heart?
But now my lord: my message being done,
I must returne i'me glad I haue found your sonne.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: For thy good newes take that along with thee,
Looke here Tris, would not these
Make notable states-men? methinks state steals vpon me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And I haue knowne some steale state.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then they came neuer truely by it as I doe, but pergite porro, methinkes I could make an indifferent careles Duke.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: And I could make a notable Courtier, methinks I am begging alreadie.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O myne Vncle would make an Excellent Court spaniell, he would sent out offices & conceald lands, a hundred mile of, and a were my casheere but twentie yeares, I durst change liuings with him.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.l: But what employment for Horatio?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O, he would make a good grumbling surly politician, thou shalt be my politician.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I shall neuer be lou'd.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not lou'd, your reason?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I hate the base and rascall multitude,
I cannot nod, ride bare-head through the streetes,
Nor wreath my body like a Cable Hat-band
To euerie Pedler and mechannick Townes-man,
I hate the poore, am enuious at the rich,
Loue none.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, women.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Faith after a sort, I loue a good smooth face.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then you loue mine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And fortie more.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I muse yoe doe not marrie.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I would to night, vpon condition
That I might burie her to morrow, God Boy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Fill him some wine.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I cannot drinke, god boy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: It is not poyson'd.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hum, I cannot tell,
The Countesse drunke and dide.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Farwell.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
Still in the bags of Melancholly, pax on't, tis staler
then Tobacco, not so much but the singing Cobler is growne melancholly, and correctes shoes in humour, fie ont, come sit, we must talke about many matters, Riuo, Ile bee singuler, my Royall expence shall run such a circular course that the Rascall spawne of Imitators shall split their wooden braines, and sinke their wealth in the Gulfe of prodigalitie, and yet like a bad Archers shaft, fall sixescore short of their ayme, my expence shall be royall and peculiar.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Ile fashion you a course.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Diuinely, come.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Diuinely indeede, serue God, liue honestly, rellish not Atheisme.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thats cleane out of the fashion indeede.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then good.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Because out of the fashion, set downe that Adam

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Tis done.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I hau't my Lord, I haue't yfaith.

sp.speaker: Po
sp.l: Nay quickly, how?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Weele keepe no Pages.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Excellent, that's cleane out of the fashion for Pages, that's good, that stands, downe with it Adam.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Tis done sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Weele vse no great Horses.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How shall we ride then?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: On Mules and shee Asses.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Downe with that Adam.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But, for my traine, for a Page with Pages,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Maintaine a hundred Gallants at your heeles,
Liue in the Countrie, entertaine agen
Into the Court, long-banish'd hospitalitie,
sp.p: Who since the first great hose with Codpeeces grewe out of fashion neere durst shew his head.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Another, set it downe, ile spend after fortie pound a day, ile see which of my cheuerill braind immitators dares follow my fashion: sblood I cannot drinke Tobacco
two daies, but the third the Church wardens & fidemen are at it in the Alehouse in sermon time, I cannot weare a sute halfe a day but the Tailors Iourny-man creepes into't: I cannot keepe a block priuate, but euery Citizens sonne thrusts his head into it: I cannot keepe a wench but euery grand-Iurors sonne in the Countre imitates me, I care not if I make it petty treason for any man to kisse vnder ten pound a Kisse.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Oh my Lord, twill neuer passe ith the Lower-house, they will not loose their libertie of kissing.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then keepe a leash of Wenches.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: As common as cracking of nuts, not a seruingman, but doth as much.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Fore-god I hau't, peculiar I haue't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What ist Iulio?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Your honour shall keepe no wenches at all.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No wenches? what shall become of me then?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I must be round with you Tris, you must pack, many women they say are common, and ile entertaine nothing that sauors of Communitie, I wil not diuulge.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Nay, but hark you my Lord, though you maintaine me, you doe not lye with me, and I thinke that's the newer fashion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Fore-god the newest of all, for there's not a gallant maintaines his wench but a will lye with her, downe with that Adam.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Tis done.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: My Lord my Lord, the Duke your father with a great traine is comming.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: From heauen or hell.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: That's more then I knowe, but by the faith of a page, or the worde of a Gent. which you will, hee is ariu'd and in great state entred the Cittie.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Zounds wheres the slaue that brought the false report of his death?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But art sure tis my father?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Or else your Mother did you the more wrong, shift for your selues, for he is come.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My father aliue and come home, hart a me what shift? come home & finde the Court turnd Ale-house Dicing-house, Dauncing schoole, I am vndone horse and foote.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Some Rosasolis or Aqua mirabilis ho, for our generall coward's in a swoune.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: I know you are a hot shot in a feather-bed Tris, but that will uot serue turne now, therefore fall off, the enemie is too strong, deede Tris, euerie Lambe to his fold, and Cony to her Borough, for the olde Foxe is abroad no, wilt not bee? why then God a mercyes braine.
Cedant arma togae, my gowne and bookes boy, some sudden deuise to keepe him back halfe an houre, and win my good opinion for euer.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: And I doe not, let mee die of the bastinasdoe.

div.stage: Enter Duke Ferneze, Angelo, and other Nobles attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lords, make a stand, I wonder that our Sonne glads not our wisht arriuall with his presence.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No doubt my Lord, his honourable care,
Is not acquainted with your sudden landing.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: We take it so, and whilst our selfe in person
Enquire the cause, attend vs in the Hall,
Little thinkes he his father is so neere,
But vnexpected, ile goe startle him,
And put his wit vnto the present try all.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: where's the Prince?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: my most honor'd Lord?
In priuate conference with an English poast.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: An English poast?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: An English post my Lord: the effect of his letters I know, not but I heard him begin a most strange discourse.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Of what I prithee?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Please your honor take a turne or two, I shall relate (quickly my Lord) hee reports there fell such an Inundation of waters in the moneth of Iuly, about the third of dog-dayes, that the Oar and Scullers that vse to worke in the Thames, rowd ouer houses & landed their faires in the middle Ile of Paules.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ist possible?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Very easely possible (sfoot quickly) and more the fishermen that rid betweene Douer and Calis, tooke red spurlin, and she Mackerell in the midst of the Exchange, which made mutton so cheepe and stale, that it is thought the better halfe of the townes-men will run horne mad about it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Not be? why looke you sir,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nay.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p:
But heare the conclusion, iust on Saint Lukes day coming shal be a twelue-month, Westminster & Winchester, drinking a quart of wine together on Salisbury-playne fell into hard words and strange termes, there was thou knaue and I knaue, and such foule words, as if tow young Barristers had bene breathing their wits for a wager, (sfoot make an ende) now it was thought Westminster stood most vpon his termes, yet in the end Winchester got one of his best termes
from him spight on his teeth, which so vext Westminster, that it grew to a deadly fewd, which was so hottly pursude that the taking vp of the matter cost many broken heads.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.p: So sir, (sfoot not done yet?) and had not Charing-crosse a tall bow legd Gent: taken vp the matter, tis thought Westminster stones would haue bin too hot for some of them: and in parting the fray, Charing-crosse got such a box o'the eare, that hee will carry it to his deathsday, some say a got a wry neck by parting the fray, marry Winchester sayes flatly, a got a creeck in his neck, with looking westward for Termers.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou shouldst haue tolde me.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Of the English poast: why looke you my Lord, the poast comming in poast-hast to shew his duty to the Prince, stumbled at a post that lay in his way and broke his sinister shanck, and so I breake of my discourse and bid your honor welcome home.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: What a strange tale is here? of flouds and hills of Charing-crosse, Termes, and I know not what? and when I loo'd for the conclusion.
sp.l: A breaks of all and leaues me in a Cloud.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: There is some trick in't, honord Iulio?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Health to my Soueraigne.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How fares our Sonne?
Haue your inducements drawn him from his humor?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Faith my Lord I haue done a childes part, and almost spent a childes part, to draw him to society, but tis labor lost.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is his businesse with the English poast?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p:
The English poast my Lord? your grace is
merry.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: His boy informd mee a held conference,
Bout serious matters with an English poast.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, the boy is lunatique.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How lunatique? and afore god me thought
A tolde a mad discourse, but th' occasion.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: I tell you my Lord, comming a abruptly as your honor or any else may do to the Princes chamber, about some ordinarie seruice, a found him in his study, and a company of botlnos'd Deuils dauncing the Irish hay about him, which on the sudden so startled the poore boy, as a cleane lost his wittes, and euer since talkes thus idle, as your Excelence hath heard him

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: But tell mee doth my sonne conuerse with Deuils?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: As familiarly as you and I, they are his only company keepers, when a hath bene duld at his study, I haue knowne a Deuill and hee play at Ticktack for phillips, by the whole day together.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Tis passing strange, but may wee without danger go neere his study?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: At your honors pleasure,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: See where a sits, be Patient and obserue.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: preuented still? now by Medusass snakes,
And black Erinnis euer burning lampe,
If all the skill in pyromantique rules,
Deep Eromancy, or the precious soule,
Of Germanique spells and Characters
Grauen in the surfase of our mother earth,
Can worke this strange atcheiuement,

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: How his braine sweates in pursuite of learning

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Oh attend.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: The first house is vulgariz'd, the Horoscop or Angle of the Orient, and his Ascendant betokeneth beginning of life, Marchandise, marriage and—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lets breake him off.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: So please your excellence.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: The second and third house, the third House is cadent from the Angle of the Orient, and Ascendant to the Angle Septenttionall, signifying Fathers Sisters and Daughters absent and lost, Daughters and fathers lost: here then I finde my demaund, the Maid lost my Sister, thus then I proportion my figure, there I place my witnesses, and heere my Iudge, and thus proceede to the Inuocation.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Renowned Prince, Prince Polymetes, zoundes Prince.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Discourteous Iulio, giue my studdie leaue.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Hart not a iot, the Duke your father.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ile make my father ioyfull by my toile,
Had not thy folly interrupted me,
My hopes ere this had met their period.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Your princely father.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O torment me not with his remembrance.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: S'blood hee's safe returnd.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: O would a were, then should not Genoaes Crowne,
For want of strong supportance be prest downe.
Ist not enough, that like a harmeles Prince
Spending my houres in Contemplation,
I let you holde the raines of gouerment.
Vnfit for me, my father hath a deepe
And searching iudgement that can brush and sweepe
such idle brayn'd and antique Parasites,
Forth of his presence, pray your absence,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I can but smile to sue how Protheus like,
They turne the shape of their discourse & proiect,
Thinking to leade me in an idle maze,
after their folly, well, Ile temporize,
and note the issue, come my Lords let's in,
His humour's grounded, and like subtle fier:
The more supprest, it mounts so much the hier.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Why so, this iest came smoothly of and was not soild in the working

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: That boy is worth his waight in pearle, dist marke what a tale of a Cock and a Bull, he tolde my father whilst I made thee and the rest away, by a bill of Conueyance at his back?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: And I did simple Knights seruice in perswading the Duke the boy was lunatique.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: twas admirable, doth not this iest deserue to be chronicled?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: No by my troth, yet I must needs say, some as bad haue bin, for how soeuer our practise passe currant with your father for the present, our villanyes must needs break forth, they are so notorious and publique.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: No matter let 'am, haue not we brayns? brayns and they be well mincde are sauce for any meate, let mine vncle turne Turxe and break forth, let the whole towne turne cuckold and blow their hornes in our disgrace, I haue brains, let the Sunne and the seauen Stars be oppos'd, I haue brayns for that too my present wit shall giue 'am all the lye in their throates, and may ntayne it at pocket, dagger, and pistoll when I haue done.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A mourner boy? what solemne funerall,
Hath hung that sable liuery on thy back?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Her death my Lord that hath cut out the like,
For both your honors, the Countesse is deceast.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then will my vncle be a hauy mourner.
But how the manner of her death?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Ile tell your honor that hereafter and giue you the ground of an admirable ieast.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And we play not true moals and worke it out of the ground, let me dye of the greene-sicknsses.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The ground then comes?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No Ile tell you that in priuate, the life of a iest thriues in the first reuealing, it concernes the manner of your avnts death and a law-trick of your vncle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Come to the solempe rites, and weepe at least those being ended wele receiue your iest. Exeunt .Solemnpe Musique to a funerall song the Herse borne ouer the stage, Duke Lurdo, Polymetes, Angelo, Iulio, Horatio and mouners &c.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What is a man? hart a the Deuill meere fools,
His rich inuention, Machiuilian plots:
Idle illusiue antick phantasies.
Apelles grapes, I had as full a brayne,
Fertile inuention and as forward hopes,
